title: Christmas general election could see nativity plays cancelled across the country
text:
Caption: General Election could see nativity plays cancelled across Britain

Pictures: Getty/PA

Nativity plays across Britain could be cancelled as primary schools and church halls may need to be commandeered for polling stations.

Boris Johnson finally secured a pre-Christmas vote after Jeremy Corbyn announced Labour’s condition of taking a no-deal Brexit off the table had been satisfied.

After haggling over the date of the poll, MPs backed a Government Bill for an election on Thursday, December 12.

The date is set to cause havoc with the festive calendar as schools and church halls that usually double as polling stations have already been earmarked to host nativity plays.

Parents and teachers took to social media to voice their concerns at the potential clashes.

If we have a general election, can it be 9th please as we’ve got the village hall booked for our school nativity on 12th and it’s used as a polling station. Don’t be inconsiderate! 😫@BorisJohnson @BBCNews @BBCPolitics — TeacherinWonderland (@nades359) October 29, 2019

Every primary school in the land realising the general election clashes with the nativity and the dates have already gone out to the parents. pic.twitter.com/fJxic5a4IP — Ashley Booth (@MrBoothY6) October 29, 2019

Think I've found the first cute-small-child-in-teatowel casualty of this blummin' #GeneralElection: just checked @StPaulsSchBford calendar and it's Nursery Nativity that day. And the nursery is usually used as a polling station. #Nativitymaggedon #nolittleangels #GE19 — ATsang (@AOfTsang) October 29, 2019

If we are heading towards a #GeneralElection on 12th December please spare a thought for all the nativity plays and end of term productions that are going to be displaced to make room for polling stations. If you can help to accommodate please do. — Edward Morello (@LibDemEM) October 24, 2019

Andrew Smith wrote: ‘Just checked – our local primary school, which our girls attended and has been our polling station for 30 years has its reception Nativity play on December 12.’

Edward Morello also asked that thought be given to ‘all the nativity plays and end of term productions that are going to be displaced to make room for polling stations’.

However, others were more welcoming of the news, suggesting a Christmas vote may save them from having to sit through the festive productions.

Pete Smith remarked that he ‘would have thought parents up and down the land would be rejoicing at the thought of all those cancelled nativity plays’.

I would have thought parents up and down the land would be rejoicing at the thought of all those cancelled nativity plays. 5 mins to vote or 1-2 hours of torture https://t.co/WJPeIavc4E — pete smith (@MainecoonPete) October 29, 2019

As a mother of 3, I just want to say that if a Christmas election risks closing schools for polling stations and cancelling all the interminable nativity plays then I FOR ONE AM WILLING TO MAKE THAT SACRIFICE. — Felicity Hannah (@FelicityHannah) October 24, 2019

Mr Johnson and Mr Corbyn will lock horns in Parliament for the final time today before it is dissolved ahead of the election.

The Commons approved the early vote on Tuesday in the hope of breaking the Brexit deadlock.

It will be the first December election in Britain for 96 years.

The UK is on course for a December general election after Jeremy Corbyn announced that Labour’s conditions to back the move had been met (Picture: PA)

The December 12 date looks set to clash with nativity plays up and down the country (Picture: Getty Images/Ariel Skelley/Blend Images LLC)

Many will need to be cancelled or moved as schools and community halls will be needed for polling stations (Picture: Getty Images)

description: The December 12 general election is expected to play havoc with the festive calendar.
